clinical_study.brief_title: Serratus Plane Block With Parenteral Opioid Analgesia Versus Patient Controlled Analgesia in Rib Fractures
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Serratus Plane Block With Parenteral Opioid Analgesia Versus Patient Controlled Analgesia Alone in Acute Rib fracturEs

lead_sponsor.agency: Chelsea and Westminster NHS Foundation Trust

collaborator.agency: St George's University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: Chelsea and Westminster NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: In this multicentre randomised controlled trial, adult patients with isolated chest trauma and two or more unilateral rib fractures will be randomised to either serratus plane block and patient controlled analgesia or patient controlled analgesia alone. Our primary outcome is the static visual analogue scale score at one hour.

primary_outcome.measure: Static visual analogue score (0-10) at 1 hour
primary_outcome.description: Defined as pain score at rest

secondary_outcome.description: Defined as pain score on deep inspiration
Defined as pain score at rest
Amount of intravenous morphine consumed within each 24 hour period
Calculated as a percentage of predicted
Assessed using the Ramsay Sedation Scale (1-6) and a value of 2 is considered the best outcome
Defined as a systolic blood pressure less than 90 mmHg
Assessed using the Nausea-Vomiting Scale (1-4) and lower values are considered a better outcome
Defined as a respiratory rate of less than 12 breaths per minute
Defined as the number of days the patient stayed in hospital

arm_group.arm_group_label: Serratus plane block and patient controlled analgesia
arm_group.description: Initial local anaesthetic bolus of 0.4 ml/kg of 0.25% levobupivacaine. Subsequent continuous local anaesthetic infusion of 0.125% levobupivacaine Patient controlled analgesia programmed with morphine to deliver on demand boluses of 1 mg and limited by a lockout time of 5 minutes
Patient controlled analgesia programmed with morphine to deliver on demand boluses of 1 mg and limited by a lockout time of 5 minutes

intervention.description: Placement of initial local anaesthetic bolus and catheter for continuous infusion in the plane between latissimus dorsi and serratus anterior in the midaxillary line at the level of the 5th rib
intervention.arm_group_label: Serratus plane block and patient controlled analgesia

intervention.description: Computerised pump device facilitating the patient self administration and titration as needed of morphine
intervention.arm_group_label: Serratus plane block and patient controlled analgesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age or older
- Isolated chest trauma
- Two or more unilateral rib fractures
Exclusion Criteria:
- Bilateral rib fractures
- Clavicular fractures
- Polytrauma
- Sternal fracture or injury
- Thoracic spine injury
- Decreased Glasgow Coma Scale score
- Dementia
- Delirium or psychiatric illness
- Chronic lung disease
- Coagulopathy
- End stage liver disease
- Significant renal failure, defined as a creatinine >150Âµmol/l
- Local infection at potential site of SBP insertion
- Pregnancy or breastfeeding
- History of chronic pain or opioid dependence
- Current chronic analgesic therapy
- Requirement for tracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation
- Allergy to local anaesthetics and/or opioids
- Inability to control and self-administer opioids with PCA due to confusion, learning difficulties or poor manual dexterity
- Unable to speak and/or understand English
